case_name: Petlad Turkey Red Dye Works Ltd. v. Respondent No. 1

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 258 of 1958 filed by the employer Petlad Turkey Red Dye Works Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 258 of 1958. Appeal by special leave from the Award dated August 17, 1957, of the Industrial Tribunal, Bombay, in Reference  IT  No. 15 of 1957.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the Award dated August 17, 1957 of the Industrial Tribunal, Bombay in Reference IT No. 15 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Award dated August 17, 1957, of the Industrial Tribunal, Bombay, in Reference  IT  No. 15 of 1957. M. Nanavati, S. N. Andley, J.B. Dadachanji and Rameshwar Nath, for the appellant.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal awarded Rs. 9,839 equivalent to one month's basic wages as bonus to employees.

anchor.surface_text: against the award of an industrial Tribunal of a sum of Rs. 9,839 equivalent to one months basic wages is as regards the companyrectness of the disallowance, in the process of ascertaining the available surplus,

facts.text: Employer claimed interest at 4% on Rs. 2,27,000 standing in the depreciation fund used as working capital.

anchor.surface_text: of a claim of 4 interest on Rs. 2,27,000 standing in the depreciation fund said to .have been used as working capital. If this claim was allowed and the amount claimed deducted as a prior charge numbersurplus would remain so that the employees would number be entitled to any bonus.

facts.text: If interest claim allowed, no surplus remaining for employees' bonus.

anchor.surface_text: If this claim was allowed and the amount claimed deducted as a prior charge numbersurplus would remain so that the employees would number be entitled to any bonus. The Industrial Tribunal was of opinion that even if the depreciation reserve was utilized as working capital numberreturn thereon was allowable for the purposes of deciding on the amount to be deducted as prior charges in applying the Full Bench Formula.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal opined that no return allowable on depreciation reserve even if utilized as working capital.

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Tribunal was of opinion that even if the depreciation reserve was utilized as working capital numberreturn thereon was allowable for the purposes of deciding on the amount to be deducted as prior charges in applying the Full Bench Formula. In this view it was clearly wrong.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that return on reserves utilized as working capital is deductible as prior charge.

anchor.surface_text: In this view it was clearly wrong. Numerous decisions of this Court make it abundantly clear that any portion of the reserve actually utilized as working capital in the year under companysideration should be treated as entitled to a reasonable rate of return and the amount thus ascertained deducted as a prior charge in ascertaining the available surplus.

facts.text: No material on record to prove Rs. 2,27,000 depreciation fund was used as working capital.

anchor.surface_text: The question remains, however, whether this amount of Rs. 2,27,000 in the depreciation fund was actually used as working capital. The Tribunal did number think it necessary to companysider this question, as in its view even if this entire amount has been utilised as working capital numberreturn was allowable.

facts.text: Employer in written statement claimed Rs. 32,000 as interest on reserves as working capital at 4%.

anchor.surface_text: All that we have is that the employer Company in its written statement claimed interest on reserves as working capital at Rs. 32, 000 the rate of return being mentioned as 4. It ,as number mentioned therein in so many words that the depreciation fund was part of the reserves employed as working capital.

facts.text: Workers in Exhibit U1 showed Rs. 3,000 deductible on working capital of Rs. 1,50,000 at 2%.

anchor.surface_text: We find that in Exhibit U I a statement submitted on behalf of the workers companytaining calculations for the available surplus Rs. 3,000 was shown as the amount deductible on working capital at 2. That is, a sum of Rs. 1,50,000 out of the reserves was stated to have been used as working capital.

facts.text: Employer's Exhibit C/3 dated July 12, 1957 shows deduction of Rs. 32,000 interest at 4% on reserves as working capital.

anchor.surface_text: The employers statement in Exhibit C/3 dated July 12, 1957, shows a deduction of Interest at 4 on Reserves employed as working capital-Rs. 32,000. A similar claim is made in Ex. C/4, an alternative statement filed on behalf of the employer on July, 12,1957.

facts.text: Exhibit C/4 alternative statement filed by employer on July 12, 1957 claiming Rs. 32,000 interest on reserves as working capital.

anchor.surface_text: A similar claim is made in Ex. C/4, an alternative statement filed on behalf of the employer on July, 12,1957. The workmen also filed a statement showing calculations of bonus made by them on the same date i.e., July, 12, 1957.

facts.text: Workmen's Exhibit U/3 dated July 12, 1957 shows return at 4% on working capital of Rs. 1,66,000.

anchor.surface_text: The workmen also filed a statement showing calculations of bonus made by them on the same date i.e., July, 12, 1957. This is marked as Ex. U/3. According to this, return at the rate of 4 on working capital of Rs. 1,66,000 was allowable as deduction.

facts.text: According to employer, reserves used as working capital not less than 8 lakhs.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, according to workmen, the reserves used as working capital was stated to be Rs. 1,66,000 while according to the employer this amount was numberless than 8 lakhs. It is quite clear therefore that the workmen had at numberstage admitted either expressly or by implication the employers claim that any portion of the depreciation fund was utilized as working reserve.

facts.text: Balance-sheet shows sum of Rs. 2,27,000 as depreciation fund.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant it was strenuously companytended, however, that the balance-sheet of the Company which was placed before the Industrial Tribunal will itself show that the entire sum of depreciation fund of Rs. 2,27,000 was used as working capital. The balance-sheet does show a sum of Rs. 2,27,000 as the depreciation fund.

facts.text: Balance-sheet does not prove that depreciation fund was utilized as working capital.

anchor.surface_text: Assuming for the purposes of the present case that this was the actual sum standing in the depreciation reserve the further question is whether the balance-sheet proves that this sum was utilized as working capital.

facts.text: No evidence on correctness of statements in balance-sheet.

anchor.surface_text: Assuming further for the -purposes of this case that the analysis of the statement made in the balance-sheet might indicate that this sum companyld number but have been utilised as working capital, it has to be remembered that numbersuch companyclusion is possible unless it is known as a fact that the statements made in the balancesheets under the different heads are companyrect statements. On that there is absolutely numberevidence.

facts.text: Court refused to remand the matter to Industrial Tribunal for further evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants companynsel finally asked that the matter may be sent back to the Industrial Tribunal and an opportunity given to him to adduce proper evidence on this point. anchor.surface_text: Numerous decisions of this Court make it abundantly clear that any portion of the reserve actually utilized as working capital in the year under companysideration should be treated as entitled to a reasonable rate of return and the amount thus ascertained deducted as a prior charge in ascertaining the available surplus. There is numberreason whatsoever for making an exception in this respect as regards depreciation reserves.

anchor.surface_text: As was pointed out by Subba Rao, J. in that case the balancesheet of a Company is prepared by the Companys own officers and when so much depends on the ascertainment of what portion of the reserve was utilized as working capital, the principles of equity and justice demand that an Industrial Court should insist upon a clear proof of the same and also give a real and adequate opportunity to the labour to canvass the companyrectness of the particulars furnished by the employer.

holdings.text: Numerous decisions of this Court make it abundantly clear that any portion of the reserve actually utilized as working capital in the year under companysideration should be treated as entitled to a reasonable rate of return and the amount thus ascertained deducted as a prior charge in ascertaining the available surplus. There is numberreason whatsoever for making an exception in this respect as regards depreciation reserves.

anchor.surface_text: Numerous decisions of this Court make it abundantly clear that any portion of the reserve actually utilized as working capital in the year under companysideration should be treated as entitled to a reasonable rate of return and the amount thus ascertained deducted as a prior charge in ascertaining the available surplus. There is numberreason whatsoever for making an exception in this respect as regards depreciation reserves.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows numerous prior Supreme Court decisions establishing the principle; explicitly rejects any exception for depreciation reserves.

holdings.text: On an examination of the record, however, we cannot discover any such material.

anchor.surface_text: On an examination of the record, however, we cannot discover any such material. All that we have is that the employer Company in its written statement claimed interest on reserves as working capital at Rs. 32, 000 the rate of return being mentioned as 4. It ,as number mentioned therein in so many words that the depreciation fund was part of the reserves employed as working capital.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Examination of record shows no evidence of actual utilization of depreciation fund as working capital.

holdings.text: Assuming that this is so it still remained the duty of the Company to prove that any portion of the depreciation fund was actually utilised as working capital.

anchor.surface_text: It is claimed however that such an averment was implicit in the claim of Rs. 32,000 as the amount allowable as return on reserves employed as working capital. Assuming that this is so it still remained the duty of the Company to prove that any portion of the depreciation fund was actually utilised as working capital.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Even assuming implicit averment in written statement, employer has duty to adduce proof of actual utilization.

holdings.text: We must therefore reject the contention urged on behalf of the employer-appellant that the balance-sheet that has been filed is sufficient to prove that Rs. 2,27,000 of the depreciation fund was actually used as working capital.

anchor.surface_text: We must therefore reject the contention urged on behalf of the employer-appellant that the balance-sheet that has been filed is sufficient to prove that Rs. 2,27,000 of the depreciation fund was actually used as working capital. There is, as we have already stated, numbermaterial on the record from which any conclusion can be reached as regards the utilisation of the whole or any portion of this sum lying in depreciation fund as working capital.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Balance-sheet prepared by company officers not self-proving; requires verification by affidavit/testimony; follows Khandesh Spg. Weaving Mill, Trichinopoly Mills; distinguishes Indian Hume Pipe; analogy to medical certificate.

holdings.text: There is, as we have already stated, no material on the record from which any conclusion can be reached as regards the utilisation of the whole or any portion of this sum lying in depreciation fund as working capital.

anchor.surface_text: There is, as we have already stated, numbermaterial on the record from which any conclusion can be reached as regards the utilisation of the whole or any portion of this sum lying in depreciation fund as working capital. holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence despite claims in statements and balance-sheet; leads to upholding disallowance of claim.

holdings.text: We do number see any circumstance that will justify us in making an order of remand in a case of this nature.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No special circumstances warrant remand despite lack of evidence.

precedents.citation: Khandesh Spg. Weaving Mill Co., Ltd. v. The Rashtriya Girni Kamgar Sangh. Jalgaon  Civil Appeal No. 257 of 1958

anchor.surface_text: Khandesh Spg. Weaving Mill Co., Ltd. v. The Rashtriya Girni Kamgar Sangh. Jalgaon  Civil Appeal No. 257 of 1958 . As was pointed out by Subba Rao, J. in that case the balancesheet of a Company is prepared by the Companys own officers and when so much depends on the ascertainment of what portion of the reserve was utilized as working capital, the principles of equity and justice demand that an Industrial Court should insist upon a clear proof of the same and also give a real and adequate opportunity to the labour to canvass the companyrectness of the particulars furnished by the employer.

precedents.case_name: Khandesh Spg. Weaving Mill Co., Ltd. v. The Rashtriya Girni Kamgar Sangh
precedents.cited_proposition: balance-sheet of a Company is prepared by the Company's own officers and when so much depends on the ascertainment of what portion of the reserve was utilized as working capital, the principles of equity and justice demand that an Industrial Court should insist upon a clear proof of the same and also give a real and adequate opportunity to the labour to canvass the correctness of the particulars furnished by the employer

precedents.citation: Indian Hume Pipe Company Ltd. v. Their Workmen  1

anchor.surface_text: Indian Hume Pipe Company Ltd. v. Their Workmen  1  which was relied upon for an argument that the balance-sheet was good evidence to prove that amounts were actually used as working capital. As was pointed out in Khandesh Spg. Weaving Mills Case  Supra  this observation was number intended to lay down the law that a balance-sheet by itself was good evidence to prove any fact as regards the actual utilisation of reserves as working capital.

precedents.case_name: Indian Hume Pipe Company Ltd. v. Their Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: observation relied upon for argument that balance-sheet was good evidence to prove amounts were actually used as working capital, but not intended to lay down that balance-sheet by itself proves actual utilisation of reserves as working capital
precedents.cited_holding: Moreover, no objection was urged in this behalf, no was any finding to the contrary recorded by the Tribunal

precedents.citation: Management of Trichinopoly Mills Ltd. v. National Cotton Textile Mills Workers Union  Civil Appeal No. 309 of 1957

anchor.surface_text: Management of Trichinopoly Mills Ltd. v. National Cotton Textile Mills Workers Union  Civil Appeal No. 309 of 1957  and it was held that the balance-sheet does number by itself prove any such fact and that the law requires that such an important  1  1959 II L.L.J- 357. fact as the utilisation of a portion of the reserve as working capital has to be proved by the employer by evidence given on affidavit or otherwise and after giving an opportunity to the workmen to contest the correctness of such evidence by cross-examination.

precedents.case_name: Management of Trichinopoly Mills Ltd. v. National Cotton Textile Mills Workers Union
precedents.cited_proposition: balance-sheet does not by itself prove utilisation of portion of reserve as working capital; must be proved by evidence on affidavit or otherwise with opportunity to workmen to contest by cross-examination

anchor.surface_text: Numerous decisions of this Court make it abundantly clear that any portion of the reserve actually utilized as working capital in the year under companysideration should be treated as entitled to a reasonable rate of return and the amount thus ascertained deducted as a prior charge in ascertaining the available surplus. There is numberreason whatsoever for making an exception in this respect as regards depreciation reserves.
